comments.body: Should the upper bound be `2.4.0` since these packages are in sync?

Good question, this is an intentional change, starting with 2.3.  The TensorBoard team has opted with this more relaxed dependency as part of a plan to release user-updates more frequently.  The minor version piece is decoupled, while the major version is still in sync.

(btw I realize the piper origin revId in the description is incorrect, just updated)
I'll also update the PR/commit description so that it's clearer.

cc @nfelt
What is the difference between `'Programming Language :: Python :: 3'` and `'Programming Language :: Python :: 3 :: Only'`? Do we need both?

- `Programming Language :: Python :: 3` means that a project does support Python 3.
- ` Programming Language :: Python :: 3 :: Only` means that a project only supports Python 3, essentially meaning that Python 2 is not supported (any more).

> Do we need both?

If you'd like to have only one of them, go with `Programming Language :: Python :: 3`.

For a similar discussion see https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/14372#discussion_r318005631.

https://packaging.python.org/guides/distributing-packages-using-setuptools/#classifiers says:

> Provide a list of classifiers that categorize your project. For a full listing, see https://pypi.org/classifiers/.
> 
> Although the list of classifiers is often used to declare what Python versions a project supports, this information is only used for searching & browsing projects on PyPI, not for installing projects. To actually restrict what Python versions a project can be installed on, use the python_requires argument.
Sounds good. Let's have both then

@@ -1,1 +301,305 @@        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.7',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.8',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3 :: Only',
        'Topic :: Scientific/Engineering',
        'Topic :: Scientific/Engineering :: Mathematics',

comments.body: I'm not seeing this package in pypi, is that going to be a problem?
Good catch - it likely will. Preparing another PR to undo some of my attempts to shove in kissfft. Thanks!
nit: I'd write either "the TensorBoard pip package" or "the tensorflow-tensorboard pip package" (because `tensorflow-tensorboard` is the pip package for the TensorBoard application).
(and `pip install tensorboard` is not what you might expect)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +62,66 @@    'saved_model_cli = tensorflow.python.tools.saved_model_cli:main',
    # We need to keep the TensorBoard command, even though the console script
    # is now declared by the tensorboard pip package. If we remove the
    # TensorBoard command, pip will inappropriately remove it during install,
    # even though the command is not removed, just moved to a different wheel.
